title: Arthur Briggs (rugby)
text:
Arthur Briggs (30 November 1867 – 18 August 1943) also known by the <a href="nickname">nickname</a> of "Spafty", was an English <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who played in the 1890s. He played at representative level for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>, and at club level for <a href="Bradford%20Park%20Avenue%20A.F.C.">Bradford F.C.</a>, as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Half-backs">half-back</a>, e.g. <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Scrum-half">scrum-half</a>, or <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Fly-half">fly-half</a>, i.e. number 9, or 10. Prior to Tuesday 27 August 1895, Bradford F.C. was a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> club, it then became a rugby league club, and since 1907 it has been the <a href="association%20football">association football</a> (soccer) club <a href="Bradford%20Park%20Avenue%20A.F.C.">Bradford Park Avenue</a>.
Background.
Arthur Briggs was born in <a href="Bradford">Bradford</a>, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, and he died aged 75 in <a href="Bradford">Bradford</a>, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>.
Playing career.
International honours.
Arthur Briggs won caps for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> while at Bradford F.C. in the <a href="1892%20Home%20Nations%20Championship">1892 Home Nations Championship</a> against Wales, Ireland, and Scotland.
Change of Code.
When Bradford F.C. converted from the <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> code to the <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> code on Tuesday 27 August 1895, Arthur Briggs would have been approximately 27. Consequently, he may have been both a rugby union and rugby league footballer for Bradford F.C.
